I worked on the waste water treatment plant in Helsinki. It's an underground facility and there are huge airpumps to pump air into those vats that have aerobic bacters. There were huge heat exchangers after the pumps so that the water where the air was pumped would not start to boil. The heat from the exchanger was used to heat the facility and it almost was enough for the whole facility. There was a powerstation using the gas that was got from the fermentation of the waste after the bacterial treatment. It's waste heat was the rest of the heat the facility needed. The electricity generated there was about half of the power need of the facility. The final waste after the fermentation were transported to nearby compost facility that made almost all the landscaping mulch that the municipal needed. Later the local power company started to use the heat of the output water to generate pipable cold.

A wooden version of this fire-piston was used throughout the Philippines before the Spaniards came in 1521. The Catholic Church believed it was of the devil and hence banned the locals from using it. Many of the fire-pistons were brought to Europe and eventually ended up in  European Museums. It is believed that Galileo who was persecuted by the Catholic Church for his scientific findings which contradicted the Church's teachings managed to get hold of this exciting but taboo gadget and had given his protege, a 14-year old Boyle who lated built a giant fire-piston based on the  wooden fire-piston. This inventions became the  basis of the diesel engine.

(p*V)/T, only 2 values may change in the equation, 3rd value is constant. Let's take a look at 3 possible things that could happen. Izothermic process - pressure goes up, volume goes down, temperature stays constant. Izobaric process - Volume becomes bigger, temperature gets bigger, pressure stays constant. Izohoric process - Pressure goes up, temperature goes up, volume doesn't change. The process in the video is Izothermic - the air's volume goes down, the pressure goes up, but temperature remains the same, meaning ignition is impossible and it is fake. What about diesel engines you ask me? Diesel engine is izothermic process too until the point when air-fuel mixture is squeezed so hard, it can't get squeezed any more, and it becomes an izohoric process, where volume can't get any smaller, so the pressure and temperature builds up.

He explained it in conjunction with the 'glowplug' when we had to change them out one winter. Because the engine block is so cold in the winter, the motor has heating rods in them to help warm up the engine so that when you turn over the motor (with the electric starter) the heat doesn't get absorbed by the engine block which doesn't allow it to accomplish an "adiabatic compression".

To everyone that is trying to say this is fake. its not. This si the basic compression principal that all engines work under to generator torque and horse power. the only difference is they used O2 and cotton as a fuel source with mass levels of friction via the rapid levels of compression to the air molecules. This friction generates enough potential energy to create the "Spark" if you will, that sets the cotton, being the furl source, on fire in turn burns up all the compressed air rapidly creating the expansion of CO2 which is why the plunger goes up before resting at the bottom.

Its the same thing in a 4 stroke engine. First you add air and fuel, then compress the air and fuel at a high rate. add heat via a spark or friction, then expansion of the explosion creates the force to drive the piston back again. in short... Suck, Squeeze,Bang,Blow. the cycle of internal combustion in a four stroke.

Top sum this up. The pressure generates friction, which generates heat, which lights the fuel source via cotton, wich creates an explosion of energy thus expansion.

You are wrong.  Glowplugs are intended to heat up the cylinders and the engine block, not the air.  Heating the air would make no sense because on the first exhaust cycle, the piston would push this warm air out of the cylinder.  If it was an intake cycle, it would pull in cold air.  Warming the air would only benefit one cylinder and only if it was at the beginning of it's compression cycle.  So yeah, you can't be more wrong.

Actually, you are both missing an important detail about the glowplugs.  Glowplugs are ONLY used when the engine is cold.  Once the engine is running, the glowplugs are not used.  Also, if then engine is still warm from recently running, they will not turn on.  Glowplugs are not REQUIRED for a diesel engine, but they help them start faster when the engine is cold.  Diesel engines can ignite fuel from compression alone.

Think of it this way. Temperature can be said to be the 'density' of energy within a substance. When the gas is compressed, it takes up a lower volume, but given that the total amount of energy present remains the same, this means that there is a higher 'density' of energy (more energy per unit volume), thus, the temperature increases.

Because you still need to ignite a fuel, the air will get hot but will not burn itself under compression.  This is exactly how diesel engines work, unlike petrol engines, there are no spark plugs, the diesel is ignited simply by piston compressing the air rapidly, which heats up, and ignites the diesel in the cylinder.

@jumptothebeats96: Thanks but I think I have to disagree with your explanation. :)  If it were true then the molecules of any gas would just get slower and slower as friction takes away all the kinetic energy.  A higher temperature means that the molecules must be moving faster than they were previously, and that can't be explained by them having less space to move in.

@dcostich Basically, pressure is directly proportional to temperature. When pressure increases, temperature also goes up.

This is because, when the pressure is increased, the amount of space for the molecules to move about in is decreased.

Though the molecules retain the same amount of kinetic energy, they collide with the surfaces more often per unit area. This results in increased friction, which generates more heat.

Actually petrol engines only use compression to a degree, and that is mostly so that the engine doesn't loose the pressure created by the explosion of gasoline that it uses to create the motion in the engine that moves through the transmission to the wheels. . The main ignition source of a petrol engine is a spark plug. Diesel engines however do use pure compression.

Diesel engines work the same way. There are no spark plugs in a diesel engine because it relies on compression. When you compress the fuel air mixture it heats up and expands, pushing the piston back down to start the process again. A large flywheel provides the momentum to allow this to keep happening until you cut off the fuel.
